question: What does the / symbol represent in a Linux file system?
choices: The user’s personal home directory
The directory used only for executables
The root directory containing all files
The temporary storage for system logs
The mount point for USB devices only

question: Why is device hardening critical for administrators?
choices: To reduce vulnerabilities and secure access
To eliminate the need for log file monitoring
To bypass authentication for trusted hosts
To prevent all user password changes
To disable all background daemons permanently

question: What is the role of the root user in Linux?
choices: It can only edit text files in the GUI
It must log in remotely to gain access
It has full control over the system
It has limited network privileges
It manages hardware but not software

question: Which toolset is known for grouping penetration testing tools?
choices: Fedora Developer Kit
CentOS Stream
Kali Linux
Debian Workstation
Ubuntu Server Edition

question: What does the package manager in Linux do?
choices: It restricts user access to system logs
It installs and manages software packages
It controls BIOS-level security updates
It encrypts system configuration files
It monitors network traffic in real time

question: What is the main function of polymorphic malware?
choices: It targets cloud-based applications exclusively
It encrypts user files and demands payment
It changes its code or behavior to evade detection
It performs denial-of-service attacks
It hides only in removable drives

question: What is the main purpose of establishing a system baseline?
choices: To improve user interface design
To measure application loading times
To reduce disk fragmentation
To create redundant backups
To identify deviations and potential vulnerabilities

question: Which Apple macOS feature ensures only notarized software is installed?
choices: Find My Mac
MRT
Gatekeeper
FileVault
XProtect

question: Which action best represents the purpose of hardening an operating system?
choices: Removing unnecessary programs and services
Reducing processor clock speed to minimize exposure
Disabling network connections permanently
Installing additional graphical interfaces
Using outdated versions for stability

question: What does Data Loss Prevention (DLP) mainly ensure?
choices: Encryption keys are stored securely in firmware
Sensitive data is not lost, misused, or accessed by unauthorized users
Data is compressed for storage efficiency
Backups are performed weekly
Email attachments are scanned for viruses

question: Which of the following best describes data in process?
choices: Data stored for disaster recovery purposes
Data being input, modified, computed, or output
Data encrypted using AES-256 standards
Data transferred through fiber optic cables
Data stored on physical drives in a data center

question: What ensures that data remains accurate and consistent throughout its lifecycle?
choices: Data integrity
Data obfuscation
Data replication
Data classification
Data redundancy

question: Which method can help verify that a file has not been altered during transmission?
choices: Tokenization
Data masking
Hashing
Encryption alone
RAID mirroring

question: Which best describes cybersecurity guidelines?
choices: Enforcement rules for software licensing
Procedures for implementing access controls
Suggestions for efficient and secure practices
Legally binding requirements for all employees
Configuration templates for system updates

question: What is one major challenge when protecting data in process?
choices: Ensuring that firewalls are properly updated
Rotating encryption keys on a strict schedule
Controlling physical access to network cables
Designing secure and reliable systems
Avoiding encryption overhead during backups

question: What is the purpose of log management in cybersecurity?
choices: To collect, store, and analyze security events
To reduce memory use by deleting old records
To replace outdated software automatically
To generate passwords from network activity
To compress large backup files for transport

question: What is one safeguard in BYOD best practices?
choices: Enforcing password-protected access
Allowing any device without registration
Sharing credentials among department teams
Installing open Wi-Fi hotspots for convenience
Disabling all backup and restore features

question: Why is obscurity considered a security strategy?
choices: It encrypts data using multiple algorithms
It replaces credentials with temporary tokens
It publishes system versions for transparency
It renames user accounts at regular intervals
It hides system details from potential attackers

question: Which statement best explains regulatory compliance?
choices: Adhering to laws and standards governing security
Submitting marketing data for vendor reviews
Writing optional procedures for internal training
Documenting employee opinions on security culture
Managing routine office software updates

question: What is the first step in identifying assets within an organization?
choices: Verify all network users have updated passwords
Create a log file for every connected device
Compare hardware configurations across departments
Schedule quarterly penetration tests on endpoints
Determine the proper asset identification category

question: What is the main purpose of the .bashrc file in a Linux user account?
choices: To define user passwords and group memberships
To manage system startup services and daemons
To customize the terminal behavior for that specific user
To control permissions for all mounted file systems
To configure the graphical desktop environment globally

question: What is the purpose of mounting a filesystem in Linux?
choices: To compress data before allocation
To make it accessible through a directory
To delete old partitions automatically
To copy it into virtual memory for faster access
To verify inode consistency at boot

question: What command can continuously monitor new entries being written to a log file?
choices: grep -live
sudo watchdog --loop
less -M
cat -repeat
tail -f

question: What is the difference between the > and >> operators?
choices: > overwrites the file, while >> appends to it
>> overwrites the file and creates a backup
Writes binary data, while >> handles text
They behave identically except for prompts
Both append, but >> requires elevated privileges

question: What does the permission string -rw-r--r-- indicate?
choices: Only the root user can execute the file
Everyone has full access to the file
Owner can read/write, others can only read
The file inherits ACL permissions dynamically
The file belongs to a network shared group

question: In Windows Local Security Policy, what does 'Enforce password history' control?
choices: Whether users can store passwords using encryption
The minimum time allowed between password resets
The number of days before a password expires
How many unique passwords must be used before reuse
How often failed logins are recorded in audit logs

question: In netstat, what does the option -p display?
choices: The last process that closed the port
The PID and name of the program using a port
The log file path for network statistics
The network device associated with the socket
The parent process ID only

question: Why does John the Ripper use a wordlist with rules?
choices: To encrypt recovered passwords safely
To skip brute-force mode entirely
To restrict cracking to administrator accounts
To try password variations intelligently
To hash passwords using SHA algorithms

question: Why does Lynis recommend setting a password on GRUB?
choices: To allow systemd to manage boot order
To block unauthorized single-user boot access
To bypass BIOS hardware checks automatically
To enable custom plug-ins for boot testing
To prevent kernel panic errors during updates

question: Why does a strong password resist recovery by John the Ripper?
choices: It was created using the passwd cache tool
It uses lowercase characters only
It is stored outside the shadow file
It’s not found in common dictionaries
It matches default Linux password length

question: In the malware PowerShell script, what is the purpose of the variable $NUzAMAR?
choices: It keeps system registry backup entries
It defines the sandbox virtual machine path
It holds event log timestamps from Windows
It stores URLs used to download malicious files
It records encryption keys for local files

question: Why is anycast used in modern DNS infrastructure?
choices: To distribute traffic and resist DDoS attacks
To synchronize DNSSEC keys faster
To authenticate recursive resolvers
To limit TTL propagation delays
To allow only IPv6-based name resolution

question: What is a DNS Zone?
choices: A temporary cache of DNS responses
A backup file containing DNS query history
A region assigned to Internet service providers
A protocol for UDP message segmentation
An administrative section of the namespace

question: Which record maps a domain name to an IPv4 address?
choices: SRV record
NS record
A record
PTR record
CAA record

question: Why is DNS described as a hierarchical system?
choices: Every DNS record depends on the same registrar
All servers synchronize from one master node
It uses blockchain-style distributed ledgers
Each level delegates authority to the next
It requires root-level credentials for every lookup

question: What is the function of the TC (truncated) bit in DNS?
choices: Requests retransmission of previous queries
Indicates a mismatch between zone transfers
Confirms that the resolver must use recursion
Marks the end of a DNSSEC validation chain
Signals that the message is too large for UDP
